creditline: Collection of Yvonne and Gabriel P. Weisberg
description: cat. 40; large oak trees near center with house hidden behind them; path winds to house; beige paper; white mat; modern light stained wood frame
medium: Charcoal heightened with white chalk and white gouache on cream paper laid down on board
text: Maxime Lalanne was an influential proponent of the charcoal landscape. He made his Salon debut in 1852 with a group of charcoal drawings and continued to exhibit such works for the next thirty years. His subjects often reflected the environs of his native Bordeaux. In fact, this drawing quite possibly shows the grounds of his own home. To highlight certain areas of the composition, Lalanne added white gouache (on the foreground plants) and a gentle dusting of white chalk (mainly on the leafy trees).
title: Landscape with a House behind Large Oak Trees near Bordeaux
